description.narrative: The project will build upon HAI’s important anti-trafficking achievements to-date, as well as lessons learned over the past five years, to provide high-impact, high-quality protection and reintegration services to VoT. HAI will also leverage its existing relationships to advance its government-level advocacy and coordination work, increasing the project’s overall efficacy and sustainability. By expanding the scope and reach of these efforts across South Kivu, HAI will ensure that VoT have access to the quality services they so desperately need, and that key stakeholders are increasingly held accountable for their role in strengthening protection and prevention mechanisms.

This project will continue to provide critical, holistic protection support to VoT, including trauma-informed mental health services, economic reintegration, emergency shelter, mobile medical services, and legal assistance. HAI, in collaboration with local partners, will also strengthen coordination and collaboration between civil society and the Government of the DRC (GoDRC) by establishing a formal mechanism that enables diverse stakeholders to proactively identify VoT and refer them to appropriate care. HAI will also independently track and monitor trafficking in persons (TIP) cases, devising a unified system for documenting and collecting data that will be used to assess progress and inform recommendations to the GoDRC. HAI will also conduct public awareness campaigns to prevent TIP through community education and mobilization, innovative radio broadcasts, and training for community focal points.
